div.head: Scaena prima

sp.speaker: Malfort.
sp.l: AND as I told you Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I understand you,
Clarinda's still perverse.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Shee's worse, obdurate,
Flinty relentlesse, my love-passions jeer'd at,
My presents scorn'd.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Tis strange a waiting-woman,
In her condition apt to yield, should hold out,
A man of your place, reverend beard and shape,
Besieging her.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You might adde too my wealth,
Which she contemnes, five hundred Crowns per annum,
For which I have ventur'd hard, my conscience knows it,
Not thought upon, though offer'd for a Joyinture:
This Chaine which my Lords Pesants worship, stouted;
My solemne hums and ha's, the servants quake at,
No Rhetorick with her; every houre she hangs out
Some new flag of defiance to torment me:
Last Lent my Lady cal'd me her poor John,
But now I am growne a walking Skelliton,
You may see through and through me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Indeed you are much falne away.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: I am a kinde of nothing,
As she hath made me: love's a terrible glister,
And if some Cordiall of her favours help not,
I shall like an Italian dye backward,
And breath my last the wrong way.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: As I live you have my pity; but this is cold comfort,
And in a friend lip-physick; and now I think on't,
I should doe more, and will, so you deny not
Your selfe the meanes of comfort.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Ile be hang'd first: one dram of't I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You are not jealous of any mans accesse to her?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I would not receive the Dor, but as a bosome friend
You shall direct me, still provided that
I understand who is the man, and what
His purpose that pleads for me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: By all meanes.
First, for the undertaker I am he:
The meanes that I will practise, thus—

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Pray you forward,

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You know your Lady chaste Caliste loves her.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Too well, that makes her proud.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Nay, give me leave.
This beauteous Lady, I may stile her so,
(Being the paragon of France for feature)
Is not alone contented in her selfe
To seeem, and be good, but desires to make
All such as have dependance on her like her;
For this Clarinda's liberty is restrain'd;
And though her kinsman the gate's shut against me;
Now if you please to make your selfe the doore,
For my conveyance to her, though you run
The hazard of a check for't, 'tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: It being for mine owne ends.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ile give it o're,
If that you make the least doubt otherwise:
Studying upon't? good morrow.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Pray you stay sir;
You are my friend: yet as the Proverb saies,
When love puts in, friendship is gone: suppose
You should your selfe affect her?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Do you think Ile commit Incest; for it is no lesse,
She being my cousin Germane. Fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: I had forgot that; for this once forgive me.
Onely to ease the throbbing of my heart,
(For I doe feele strange pangs) instruct me what
You will say for me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: First, Ile tell her that
She hath so far besotted you, that you have
Almost forgot to cast accompt.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Meere truth sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: That of a wise and provident Steward,
You are turn'd starke Asse.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Urge that point home, I am so.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: That you adore the ground she treads upon,
And kisse her foot-steps.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: As I doe when I finde their print in the Snow.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: A loving foole I know it,
By your bloudlesse-frosty lips: then having related
How much you suffer for her, and how well
You doe deserve it—

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: How? to suffer?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No sir, to have your love return'd.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: That's good, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I will deliver her an Inventorie
Of your good parts: as this your precious nose,
Dropping affection: your high-forehead, reaching
Almost to the crowne of your head; your slender waste,
And a back not like a threshers, but a bending
And Court-like back, and so forth, for your body.
But when I touch your minde, for that must take her,
(Since your out-side promises little) Ile enlarge it,
(Though ne're so narrow) as your Arts to thrive,
Your composition with the Cook, and Butler,
Fory Coney-skins and Chippings, and halfe a share
With all the under-officers of the house,
In strangers bounties, that she shall have all,
And you as 'twere her Bailiffe.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: As I will be.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: As you shall, so Ile promise. Then your qualities.
As playing on a Gytterne, or Jewes Trumpe.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: A little too on the Viall.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I care you nothing.
Then singing her asleep with curious catches
Of your owne making: for as I have heard,
You are Poeticall.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Something given that way.
Yet my works seldome thrive: and the main reason
The Poets urge for't, is, because I am not
As poore as they are.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Very likely: fetch her,
While I am in the vaine.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Tis an apt time, my Lady being at her prayers.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Let her pray on.
Nay goe, and if upon my intercession
She doe you not some favour, Ile disclaime her;
Ile ruminate on't the while.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: A hundred Crownes is your reward.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Without 'em— nay, no trifling. Ex. Malf.
That this dull clod of ignorance should know
How to get money, yet want eyes to see
How grossely hee's abus'd, and wrought upon,
When he should make his will, the rogues turn'd rampant,
As he had renew'd his youth: A handsome wench
Love one a spittle-whore would run away from?
Well Master Steward, I will plead for you
In such a Method, as it shall appeare
You are fit to be a propertie.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yonder he walks
That knowes my worth and value, though you scorn it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: If my Lady know not this—

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Ile answer it:
If you were a Nun, I hope your cousin German
Might talke with you through a grate, but you are none,
And therefore may come closer: ne're hang off,
As I live you shall bill: you may salute as strangers,
Custome allowes it. Now, now, come upon her
With all your Oratory, tickle her to the quick,
As a young advocate should, and leave no vertue
Of mine unmentioned, Ile stand Centinell;
Nay keep the doore my selfe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How have you work'd
This piece of motley to your ends?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Of that at leasure, Mistris. Kissing.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Lower, you are too loud,
Though the fool be deaf some of the house may hear you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Suppose they should, I am a gentleman,
And held your kinseman, under that I hope
I may be free.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I grant it, but with caution;
But be not seen to talke with me familiarly,
But at fit distance, or not seen at all,
It were the better: you know my Ladies humour,
Shee is all honour, and compos'd of goodnesse,
(As she pretends) and you having no businesse,
How jealous may she grow?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I will be rul'd.
But you have promis'd, and I must enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: We shall finde time for that; you are too hastie:
Make your selfe fit, and I shall make occasion,
Deliberation makes best in that businesse,
And contents every way.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: But you must feed
This foolish Steward with some shadow of
A future favour, that we may preserve him
To be our instrument.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Hang him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: For my sake sweet,
I undertook to speak for him, any bauble,
Or slight employment in the way of service,
Will feed him fat.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Leave him to me, Enter Malfort.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: She comes. My Lady.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I will satisfie her.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: How far have you prevail'd?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Observe.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Mounsieur Malfort.
I must be briefe, my cousin hath spoke much
In your behalfe, and to give you some proof,
I entertaine you as my servant,
You shall have the grace.

sp.speaker: Leon
sp.l: Upon your knee receive it,

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: And take it a speciall favour from me,
To tye my shooe.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: I am ore-joy'd.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Good reason.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You may come higher in time.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No more, the Lady. Enter Calista.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: She frownes.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I thanke you for this visit cousin,
But without leave hereafter from my Lady,
I dare not change discourse with you.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Pray you take your mornings draught.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I thank you: Exeunt Leon. Malfort.
Happinesse attend your honour.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.l: Who gave warrant to this private parle?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: My innocence; I hope
My conference with a kinseman cannot call
Your anger on me.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.l: Kinsman? Let me have
No more of this, as you desire you may continue mine.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Why Madam (under pardon)
Suppose him otherwise: yet comming in
A lawfull way it is excusable.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I grant you are made of purenesse,
And that your tendernesse of honour holds
The soveraigntie o're your passions. Yet you have
A noble Husband, with allow'd embraces,
To quench lascivious fires, should such flame in you,
As I must ne're believe. Were I the wife
Of one that could but zanie brave Cleander,
Even in his least perfections, (excuse
My ore-bold inference) I should desire
To meet no other object.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You grow saucie. Doe I look further?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: No, deare Madam: and
It is my wonder or astonishment rather,
You could deny the service of Lisandar;
A man without a rivall: one the King
And Kingdome gazes on with admiration,
For all the excellencies a mother could
Wish in her onely sonne.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Did not mine honour
And Obligation to Cleander, force me
To be deafe to his complaints?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis true; but yet
Your rigor to command him from your presence,
Argu'd but small compassion; the Groves
Witnesse his grievous sufferings, your faire name
Upon the rhinde of every gentle Poplar,
And amorous Myrtle, (trees to Venus sacred)
With adoration carv'd, and kneel'd unto,
This you (unseen of him) both saw and heard
Without compassion, and what receiv'd he
For his true sorrowes? but the heavy knowledge,
That 'twas your peremptory will and pleasure,
( How e're my Lord liv'd in him) he should quit
Your sight and house for ever.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I confesse I gave him a strong potion to worke
Upon his hot bloud, and I hope 'twill cure him:
Yet I could wish the cause had concern'd others,
I might have met his sorrowes with more pittie;
At least have lent some counsell to his miseries,
Though now for honour sake, I must forget him,
And never know the name more of Lisander:
Yet in my justice I am bound to grant him,
(Laying his love aside) most truely noble.
But mention him no more, this instant houre
My brother Lidian, new return'd from travaile,
And his brave friend Clarange, long since rivalls
For faire and rich Olinda, are to heare
Her absolute determination, whom
She pleases to elect: see all things ready
To entertain 'em: and on my displeasure
No more words of Lisander.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: She endures to heare him nam'd by no tongue but her owne:
How e're she carries it, I know she loves him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hard nature: hard condition of poore women!
That where we are most su'd too, we must flye most.
The trees grow up, and mixe together freely,
The Oke not envious of the sailing Cedart
The lustie Vine not jealous of the Ivie
Because she clips the Elme; the flowers shoot up,
And wantonly kisse one another hourely,
This blossome glorying in the others beauty,
And yet they smell as sweet, and look as lovely:
But we are ty'd to grow alone. O honour,
Thou hard Law to our lives, chaine to our freedomes;
He that invented thee had many curses;
How is my soule divided? O Cleander,
My best deserving husband! O Lisander!
The truest lover that e're sacrific'd
To Cupid against Hymen: O mine honour;
A Tyrant, yet to be obey'd, and 'tis
But justice we should thy strict Lawes endure,
Since our obedience to thee keeps us pure. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: How insupportable the difference
Of deare friends is, the sorrow that I feele
For my Lisanders absence, one that stampes
A reverend print on friendship, does assure me
You are rivals for a Lady, a faire Lady,
And in the acquisition of her favours,
Hazard the cutting of that Gordion knot
From your first childhood to this present houre,
By all the tyes of love and amity fastend,
I am blest in a wife (heaven make me thankefull)
Inferiour to none (sans pride I speake it)
Yet if I were a free-man, and could purchase
At any rate the certainty to enjoy
Lisanders conversation while I liv'd,
Forgive me my Caliste and the Sexe,
I never would seeke change.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: My Lord and brother,
I dare not blame your choice, Lisanders worth,
Being a Mistris to be ever courted;
Nor shall our equall suit to faire Olinda
Weaken, but adde strength to our true affection,
With zeale so long continued.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: When we know
Whom she prefers, as she can choose but one,
By our so long tride friendship we have vow'd
The other shall desist.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: 'Tis yet your purpose,
But how this resolution will hold
In him that is refus'd, is not alone
Doubtfull, but dangerous.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: The rich heire is come sir.

sp.speaker: Cleand.
sp.l: Madam Olinda.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Yes sir, and makes choice,
After some little conference with my Lady,
Of this room to give answer to her suitors.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Already both look pale, between your hopes
To win the prize, and your despaire to lose
What you contended for.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: No sir, I am arm'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I confident of my interest.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ile beleeve ye when you have endur'd the test.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Is not your garter
Unty'd? you promis'd that I should grow higher
In doing you service.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Fall off or you lose mee. Exit Malf.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Nay take your place, no Paris now sits judge
On the contending goddesses. You are
The Deitie that must make curst or happy,
One of your languishing servants.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I thus look with equal eyes on both, either deserves
A fairer fortune then they can in reason
Hope for from me; from Lidian I expect,
When I have made him mine, all pleasures that
The sweetnesse of his manners, youth, and vertues
Can give assurance of: but turning this way
To brave Clarange, in his face appeares
A kinde of majesty which should command,
Not sue for favour. If the fairest Lady
Of France, set forth with natures best endowments
Nay should I adde a Princesse of the bloud,
Did now lay claime to either for a husband,
So vehement my affection is to both,
My envie at her happinesse would kill me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The strangest love I ever heard.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You can enjoy but one.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The more I say the merrier.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Witnesse these teares I love both, as I know
You burne with equall flames, and so affect me;
Abundance makes me poore; such is the hard
Condition of my fortune; be your owne judges;
If I should favour both, 'twill taint my honour,
And that before my life I must prefer,
If one I leane to, the other is disvalewed;
You are fierie both, and love will make you warmer,

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The warmer still the fitter. You are a foole Lady.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: To what may love, and the devill jealousie spur you
Is too apparent: my name's cal'd in question:
Your swords flie out, your angers range at large:
Then what a murther of my modesty followes?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Take heed of that by any meanes: O innocent,
That will deny a blessing when 'tis offer'd,
Would I were murther'd so, I would thank my modesty.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What pause you on?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: It is at length resolved.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: We are on the Rack, uncertain expectation,
The greatest torture.

sp.speaker: Lidian.
sp.l: Command what you please,
And you shall see how willingly we will execute.

sp.speaker: Olinda
sp.l: Then heare what for your satisfaction,
And to preserve your friendship I resolve
Against my selfe, and 'tis not to be alter'd:
You are both brave gentlemen, Ile still professe it,
Both noble servants, for whose gentle offers,
The undeserving, and the poore Olinda
Is ever bound; you love both, faire, and vertuously;
Would I could be so happy to content both:
Which since I cannot, take this resolute answer;
Goe from me both contentedly, and he
That last makes his returne, and comes to visit,
Comes to my bed. You know my will: farewell;
My heart's too big to utter more: come friend.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ile wait on you to your Coach.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: You both look blank, I cannot blame you.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: We have our dispatches.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Ile home.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.p: And Ile abroad again, Farewell. Exit Clarange and Lidian.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Farewell to yee.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Their blunted departure troubles me: I feare
A suddaine and a dangerous division
Of their long love will follow: have you took
Your leave of faire Olinda? Enter Caliste with a purse.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: She is gone sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Had you brought news Lisander were return'd too,
I were most happy.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Still upon Lisander?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I know he loves me, as he loves his health:
And heaven knowes I love him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I finde it so:
For me you have forgot, and what I am to you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: O think not so If you had lost a sister,
You lock'd all your delights in, it would grieve you:
A little you would wander from the fondnesse,
You ow'd your husband: I have lost a friend,
A noble friend, all that was excellent
In man, or man-kinde, was contain'd within him.
That loste my wife—

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Madam, your noble Father—
A see for my good newes.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why? what of him sir?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Is lighted at the doore, and longs to see you.

sp.speaker: Calist.
sp.l: Attend him hither.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O my deare Lisander.
But Ile bee merry: lets meet him my Caliste.

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.l: I hope Lasanders love will now be buried:
My father will bring joy enough for one moneth,
To put him out of his memorie.

div.stage: Enter Dorilaus, his arme in a scarffe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How doe you sonne?
Blesse my faire child, I am come to visit yee,
To see what house you keep, they say you are bountifull,
I like the noyse well, and I come to trie it.
Ne're a great belly yet? how have you trifl'd?
If I had done so (sonne) I should have heard on't
On both sides by Saint Denis.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: You are nobly welcome sir:
We have time enough for that.

sp.speaker: Dorilaus.
sp.l: See how she blushes:
'Tis a good signe you'll mend your fault, how dost thou,
My good Caliste?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Well, now I see you sir;
I hope you bring a fruitfulnesse along with ye.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Good luck, I never misse, I was ever good at it:
Your mother groand for't wench, so did some other,
But I durst never tell.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How does your arme sir?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Have you been let bloud of late?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Against my will sir.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: A fall deare father?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No, a Gun, deare daughter;
Two or three Guns; I have one herein my buttock,
'Twould trouble a Surgeons teeth to pull it out.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O me! O me!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay, if you fall to fainting,
'Tis time for me to trudge: art such a coward,
At the meere name of hurt to change thy colour?
I have been shot that men might see clean through me
And yet I fainted not: besides my selfe,
Here are an hospitall of hurt men for yee.

div.stage: Enter Servants wounded in severall places.

sp.speaker: Cloan.
sp.l: What should this wonder be?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am amaz'd at it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What think ye of these? they are every one hurt soundly,
Hurt to the proof, they are through, & through I assure ye;
And that's good game, they scorne your puling scratches.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Who did this sir?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Leave crying, and Ile tell you,
And get your plaisters, and your warme stupes ready:
Have you ne're a Shepheard that can tarre us over?
'Twill proove a businesse else, we are so many.
Comming to see you, I was set upon,
I and my men, as we were singing frolickly,
Not dreaming of an ambush of base rogues,
Set on ith' forrest, I have forgot the name—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: 'Twixt this, and Fountaine-Bleiu?
In the wilde Forrest?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The same, the same, in that accursed Forrest,
Set on by villaines, that make boot of all men.
The Peeres of France are pillage there, they shot at us,
Hurt us, un-hors'd us, came to the sword, there plide us,
Opprest us with fresh multitudes, fresh shot still,
Rogues that would hang themselves for a fresh doublet,
And for a Skarlet cassock kill their fathers.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Lighted you among these?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Among these murtherers,
Our poore blouds were ingag'd: yet we strook bravely,
And more then once or twice we made them shun us,
And shrink their rugged heads: but we were hurt all.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: How came you off? for I even long to hear that.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: After our prayers made to heaven to help us,
Or to be mercifull unto our soules,
So neare we were. Alas poore wench, wipe, wipe.
See heaven sends remedy.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am glad 'tis come sir,
My heart was even a bleeding in my body.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A curl'd haire gentleman stept in, a stranger,
As he rod by, belike he heard our bickering,
Saw our distresses, drew his sword, and prov'd
He came to execute, and not to argue.
Lord what a lightning me thought flew about him,
When he once toss'd his blade; in face Adonis,
While peace inhabited between his eye-browes:
But when his noble anger stirr'd his mettle,
And blew his firie parts into a flame,
Like Pallas, when she sits between two armies,
Viewing with horrid browes their sad events,
Such then hee look'd: and as her shield had arm'd him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: This man sir were a friend to give an age for.
This gentleman I must love naturally:
Nothing can keep me off; I pray you goe on sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I will, for now you please me: this brave youth,
This bud of Mars, for yet he is no riper,
When once he had drawne bloud, and flesh'd his sword,
Fitted his manly mettle to his spirit,
How he bestirr'd him? what a lane he made?
And through their fierie Bullets thrust securely:
The hardned villaines wondring at his confidence,
Lame as I was I follow'd, and admir'd too,
And stirr'd, and laid about me with new spirit,
My men too with new hearts thrust into action,
And down the rogues went.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I am strook with wonder.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Remember but the storie of strong Hector,
When like to lightning he broke through his van-guard,
How the Greeks frighted ran away by Troops,
And trod downe Troops to save their lives: so this man,
Dispers'd these slaves: had they been more and mightier,
He had come off the greater, and more wonder.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Where is the man, good sir, that we may honor him?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: That we may fall in superstition to him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I know not that, from me he late departed,
But not without that pious care to see safe
Me, and my weak men lodg'd, and dress'd; I urg'd him
First hither, that I might more freely thanke him:
He told me he had businesse crav'd my pardon,
Businesse of much import.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Know you his name?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That he deny'd me too: a vow had bard him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: In that he was not noble to be namelesse.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Daughter you must remember him when I am dead,
And in a noble sort requite his piety,
'Twas his desire to dedicate this service
To your faire thoughts.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He knowes me then?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I nam'd you,
And nam'd you mine: I think that's all his knowledge.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: No name, no being?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Now I am mad to know him:
Saving mine honour, any thing I had now
But to enjoy his sight, but his bare picture;
Make me his Saint, I must needs honour him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I know his name.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: There's thy reward for't; speak it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: His man told me, but he desir'd my silence.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O Jasper speak, 'tis thy good Masters cause too:
We all are bound ingratitude to compell thee.

sp.speaker: Serv
sp.p: Lisander, Yes, I am sure it was Lisander.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Lisander? 'twas Lisander.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: 'Tis Lisander. O my base thoughts? my wicked?
To make question this act could be another mans:
'Tis Lisander, a handsome timber'd man.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: My Lisander! was this friends absence to bee mourn'd?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I grant it:
Ile mourne his going now, and mourne it seriously:
When you weep for him, sir, Ile beare you company.
That so much honour, so much honesty
Should be in one man, to doe things thus bravely,
Make me his Saint, to me give this brave service:
What may I doe to recompence his goodnesse?
I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Come sir, I know you are sickly, so are your men.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I must confesse I am weake,
And fitter for a bed then long discourses.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You shall hear to morrow, to morrow provide Surgeons.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Lisander—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: What new fire is this? Lisander— Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: PRethee good Lancelot remember that
Thy Masters life is in thy trust, and therefore
Be very careful.

sp.speaker: Lance.
sp.l: I will lose mine owne, rather then hazard yours.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Take what disguise
You in your owne discretion shall think fittest,
To keep your selfe unknowne.

sp.speaker: * Lanc.
sp.l: I warrant yee;
'Tis not the first time I have gone invisible:
I am as fine a Fairie in a businesse
Concerning night-worke—

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Leave your vanities:
With this purse (which deliver'd,
You may spare your Oratory) convey this Letter to
Caliste's woman.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: 'Tis a handsome girle, Mistris Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I have made her mine. You know your work.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: And if I sweat not in it,
At my returne discarde me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lisand.
sp.l: O Caliste! the fairest! cruellest!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: So early stirring? a good day to you.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I was viewing sir,
The site of your house, and the handsomnesse about it:
Believe me it stands healthfully and sweetly.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: The house and master of it really
Are ever at your service.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I returne it:
Now if you please goe forward in your storie
Of your deare friend and Mistris.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I will tell it,
And tell it short, because 'tis breakfast time,
(And love a tedious thing to a quick stomach)
You eate not yester-night.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I shall endure sir.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: My selfe (and as I then deliver'd to you)
A gentleman of noble hope, one Lidian,
Both brought up from our infancy together,
One company, one friendship, and one exercise,
Ever affecting, one bed holding us,
One griefe, and one joy parted still between us,
More then companions, twins in all our actions,
We grew up till we were men, held one heart still:
Time call'd us on to Armes, we were one souldier,
Alike we sought our dangers and our honours,
Gloried alike one in anothers noblenesse:
When Armes had made us fit, we were one lover,
We lov'd one woman, lov'd without division,
And woo'd a long time with one faire affection;
And she, as it appeares, loves us alike too.
At length considering what our love must grow to,
And covet in the end, this one was parted,
Rivalls and honours make men stand at distance.
We then woo'd with advantage, but were friends still,
Saluted fairely, kept the peace of love,
We could not both enjoy the Ladies favour,
Without some scandall to her reputation,
We put it to her choice, this was her sentence,
To part both from her, and the last returning
Should be her Lord; we obey'd, and now you know it;
And for my part, (so truely I am touch'd with't)
I will goe farre enough, and be the last too,
Or ne're returne:

sp.speaker: Lisand.
sp.l: A sentence of much cruelty;
But milde, compar'd with what's pronounc'd on me.
Our loving youth is borne to many miseries.
What is that Lidian pray ye?

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.p: Caliste's brother, if ever you have heard of that faire Ladie.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: I have seen her sir.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: Then you have seen a wonder.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: I doe confesse: of what yeares is this Lidian?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: About my years: there is not much between us.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: I long to know him.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: 'Tis a vertuous longing,
As many hopes hang on his noble head,
As blossoms on a bough in May, and sweet ones.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Ye are a faire storie of your friend.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Of truth sir: now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: There is a gentleman
At doore, would speak with you on private businesse.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: With me?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: He saies so, and brings haste about him.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Wait on him in. Exit Serv.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: I will retire the while, to the next room.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: We shall not long disturbe you. Ent. Alcidon.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Save ye sir.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: The like to you fair sir: pray you come neare.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Pray you instruct me for I know you not.
With Monsieur Clarange I would speake.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I am he sir:
Ye are nobly welcome; I wait your businesse.

sp.speaker: Alcid.
sp.l: This will informe you.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Will you please to sit down? Reads.
He shall command me sir, Ile wait upon him
Within this houre.

sp.speaker: Alcid.
sp.l: Y'are a noble gentleman,
Wil't please you bring a friend? we are two of us,
And pitty either sir should be unfurnish'd.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I have none now, and the time is set so short,
'Twill not be possible.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Doe me the honour:
I know you are so full of brave acquaintance,
And worthy friends, you cannot want a partner:
I would be loath to stand still sir; besides,
You know the custome, and the vantage of it,
If you come in alone.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: And I must meet it.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Send, wee'l defer an houre, let us be equall:
Games won and lost on equall tearmes shew fairest.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis to no purpose to send any whither,
Unlesse men be at home by Revelation:
So please you breath a while; when I have done with him
You may be exercis'd too: Ile trouble no man.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: They are very loud. Now what's the newes?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: I must leave you,
Leave you a while, two houres hence Ile returne friend.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: A little businesse.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: And't be but a little, you may take me with ye.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Twill be a trouble to you.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: No indeed, to do you service, I account a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I must alone.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Clarang.
sp.l: 'Tis necessity—
Before you passe the walks, and back agen,
I will be with ye.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: If it be not unmannerly
To presse you, I would goe.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: Ile tell you true sir,
This gentleman and I upon appointment,
Are going to visit a Lady.

sp.speaker: Lisond.
sp.l: I am no Capuchin, why should not I goe?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Take the gentleman,
Come he may see the gentlewoman too,
And be most welcome, I do beseech you take him.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: By any means, I love to see a gentlewoman,
A prettie wench too.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Well sir, wee'll meet you,
And at the place: My service to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: I kisse your hand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Prethee read o're her Letter.

sp.speaker: Lisander

body.p: I Know you have consider'd the dark sentence Olinda gave us, and that (however she disguis'd it) it pointed more at our swords edges then our bodies banishments; the last must enjoy her: if we retire, our youths ars lost in wandring; in emulation we shall grow old men, and feeble, Which is the scorne of love, and rust of honour, and so return more fit to wed our Sepulchers, then the Saint we aime at; let us therefore make our journey short, and our hearts ready, and with our swords in our hands put it to fortune, which shall be worthy to receive that blessing, Ile stay you on the mountaine, our old hunting place, this gentleman alone runs the hazzard with me, and so I kisse your hand.

sp.l: Is this your wench? you'll finde her a sharp Mistris.
What have I thrust my selfe into? is this that Lidian
You told me of?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: My Ladies brother?
No cause to heave my sword against but his?
To save the father yesterday, and this morning,
To help to kill the son? this is most courteous?
The onely way to make the daughter doat on me.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Why doe you muse? would ye goe off?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: No, no, I must on now; this will be kindly taken;
No life to sacrifice, but part of hers?
Doe you fight straight?

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Yes, presently.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: To morrow then,
The balefull tidings of this day will break out,
And this nights Sun will set in bloud; I am troubl'd:
If I am kill'd, I am happy.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Will you goe friend?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I am ready sir, fortune thou hast made me monstrous. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Malf.
sp.l: Your cousin, and my true friend, lusty Leon,
Shall know how you use me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Be more temperate,
Or I will never use, nor know you more
ith' way of a seruant: all the house takes notice
Of your ridiculous fopperie; I have no sooner
Perform'd my duties in my Ladies chamber,
And she scarce down the staires, but you appeare
Like my evill spirit to me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Can the fish live out of the water, or the Salamander
Out of the fire? or I live warme, but in
The frying-pan of your favour?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Pray you forget
Your curious comparisons, borrowed from
The pond, and kitchin, and remember what
My Ladies pleasure is forth 'entertainment
Of her noble father.

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: I would learn the art of memory in your table book.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Very good sir, no more but up and ride, I apprehend
Your meaning, soft fire makes sweet mault sir:
I'le answer you in a Provetbe,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But one kisse from thy honey lippe.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You sight too high, my hand is
A faire ascent from my foot, his slavering kisses
Spoyle me more gloves,— enough for once, you'l surfet
With too much grace.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Have you no imployment for me?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yes, yes, go send for Leon, and convey him
Into the private Arbour, from his mouth
I heare your praises with more faith.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I am gone-yet one thing ere I go, there's at the dore
The rarest Fortune-teller, he hath told me
The strangest things; he knows ye are my Mistris,
And under seale deliver'd how many children
I shall beget on you, pray you give him hearing,
He'l make it good to you.

sp.speaker: Gla.
sp.l: A cunning man
Of your own making, howsoe're I'le heare him
At your intreaty.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Now I perceive ye love me,
At my entreaty, come in friend— remember
To speake as I directed, he knows his lesson,
And the right way to please her; this it is
To have a head-peece. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Lancelot like a Fortune-teller, with a Purse, and two Letters in it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis said you can tell Fortunes to come.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Yes Mistris, and what's past;
Unglove your hand, by this straight line, I see
You have laine crooked.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How? laine crooked?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Yes; and in that posture plaid at the old game,
( No body heares me, and I'le be no blab)
And at it lost your maiden-head.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: A shrewd fellow;
'Tis truth, but not to be confess'd; in this
Your palmestry deceaves you, some thing else sir.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Ye are a great woman with your Lady, and
Acquainted with her counsels.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Still more strange.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: There is a noble Knight Lisander loves her,
Whom she regards not and the destinies
With whom I am familiar, have deliver'd
That by your meanes alone, he must enjoy her.
Your hand agen, Yes, yes; you have already
Promis'd him your assistance, and what's more,
Tasted his bounty, for which, from the skye
There are 200. crownes dropp'd in a Purse,
Looke backe, you'l find it true; nay, open it,
'Tis good Gold I assure you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How, two Letters? the first indors'd to me? this to my Lady?
Subscrib'd Lisander.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And the Fortuneteller, his servant Lancelot.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How had I lost my eyes,
That I could not know thee? not a word of the losse
Of my virginity.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: Nor who I am.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I'le use all speedy meanes for your dispatch,
With a welcome answer, but till you receive it,
Continue thus disguis'd, Mounsieur Malfort
(You know the way to humour him) shall provide
A lodging for you, and good entertainment;
Nay, since we trade both one way, thou shalt have
Some feeling with me, take that.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Bountifull wench may'st thou ne're want imployment.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nor such pay boy. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Lidian, Alcidon, (at one dore) Lisander, Clarange, (at another.)

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: You'r welcome.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Let us do our office first,
And then make choice of a new peece of ground
To try our fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: All's faire here.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: And here, their swords are equall.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: If there be any odds in mine, we will exchange.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Wee'l talke of that
When we are farther off, farwell.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Farewell friend. Ex. Lisand. and Alcid

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Come let us not be idle?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I will find you imployment, feare not.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: You know sir, the cause that brings us hether

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: There needs no more discoursing,
No time, nor place for repetition now.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Let our Swords argue, and I wish Clarange,
The proud Olinda saw us.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Would she did;
What ever estimation she holds of me,
She should behold me like a man fight for her.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: 'Tis nobly said; set on love; and my fortune—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The same for me, come home brave Lidian,
'Twas manly thrust, this token to the Lady,
Ye have it sir, deliver it, take breath,
I see ye bleed apace, ye shall have faire play.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: You must lye there a while, I cannot help you,

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Nay, then my fortunes gone, I know I must dye:
Yet dearely will I sell my love, come on both,
And use your fortunes, I expect no favour;
Weake as I am, my confidence shall meet ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yeild up your cause and live.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: What dost thou hold me?
A recreant, that prefers life before credit?
Though I bleed hard, my honour finds no Issue,
That's constant to my heart.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Have at your life then.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Hold, or I'le turne, and bend my sword against ye;
My cause Clarange too, view this brave Gentleman,
That yet may live to kill you, he stands nobly,
And has as great a promise of the day
As you can tye unto your selfe, he's ready,
His Sword as sharpe, view him with that remembrance,
That you deliver'd him to me Clarange:
And with those eyes, that clearnesse will become ye:
View him, as you reported him; survey him,
Fixe on your friendship sir, I know you are noble,
And step but Inward to your old affection,
Examine but that soule grew to your bosome,
And try then if your Sword will bite, it cannot,
The edge will turne againe, asham'd, and blunted;
Lidian, you are the patterne of faire friendship,
Exampled for your Love, and imitated,
The Temple of true hearts, stor'd with affections,
For sweetnesse of your spirit made a Saint,
Can you decline this noblenesse to anger?
To mortall anger? 'gainst the man ye love most?
Have ye the name of vertuous, not the nature?

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: I will sit downe.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: And I'le sit by you Lidian.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: And I'le go on, can heaven be pleas'd with these things?
To see two hearts that have been twin'd together
Married in friendship to the world, to wonder,
Of one growth, of one nourishment, one health,
Thus mortally divorc'd for one weake woman?
Can love be pleas'd? love is a gentle spirit,
The wind that blowes the Aprill flowers, not softer;
She is drawne with doves to shew her peacefulnesse,
Lions and bloudy Pards are Mars's servants;
Would ye serve love? do it with humblenesse,
Without a noise, with still prayers, and soft murmurs;
Upon her Altars offer your obedience,
And not your brawles; she's won with teares, not terrors:
That fire ye kindle to her deity,
Is only gratefull when it blowes with sighs,
And holy Incense flung with white hand-innocence;
Ye wound her now; ye are too superstitious,
No sacrifice of bloud, or death she longs for:

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Came he from heaven?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: He tels us truth good Lidian.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: That part of Noble love which is most sweet,
And gives eternall being to faire beauty,
Honour. You hack a peeces with your swords,
And that ye fight to crowne, ye kill faire credit.

sp.speaker: Clara.
sp.l: Thus we embrace, no more fight, but all friendship,
And where love pleases to bestow his benefits,
Let us not argue.

sp.speaker: Lid.
sp.l: Nay brave sir, come in too;
You may love also, and may hope, If he do,
And not rewarded for't, there is no justice;
Farwell friend, here let's part upon our pilgrimage,
It must be so, Cupid draws on our sorrowes.
And where the lot lights—

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: I shall count it happinesse,
Farewell deare friend.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: First, let's relieve the Gentleman
That lyes hurt in your cause, and bring him off,
And take some cure for your hurts, then I will part too,
A third unfortunate, and willing wanderer. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: My feares foresaw't would come to this.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I would your sentence had been milder.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: 'Tis past helpe now.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I share in your despaire, and yet my hopes
Have not quite left me, since all possible meanes
Are practised to prevent the mischiefe following
Their mortall meeting, my Lord is coasted one way,
My father, though his hurts forbad his travell,
Hath tooke another, my brother in Law Beronte,
A third, and every minute we must looke for
The certaine knowledge, which we must endure
With that calme patience heav'n shall please to lend us.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Dead both?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Such is the rumour, and 'tis generall.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: I heare my passing-bell.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am in a feavour.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: They say their seconds too; but what they are,
Is not known yet, some worthy fellows certain.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Where had you knowledge?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Of the Country people, 'tis spoken every where.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I heard it so too;
And 'tis so common, I do halfe beleeve it,
You have lost a brother wench, he lov'd you well,
And might have liv'd to have done his countrie service,
But he is gone, thou feld'st untimely Lidian,
But by a valiant hand, that's some small comfort,
And tooke him with thee too, thou lov'st brave company,
Weeping will do no good, you lost a servant,
He might have liv'd to have been your Master Lady,
But you fear'd that.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: Good sir, be tender to me,
The newes is bad enough, you need not presse it.
I lov'd him well, I lov'd 'em both.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It seemes so.
How many more have you to love so Lady?
They were both fooles to fight for such a Fidle;
Certaine there was a dearth of noble anger,
When a slight woman was thought worth a quarrell.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Pray you thinke nobler.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: I'le tell thee what I thinke, the plague, war, famine,
Nay put in dice and drunkennesse, and those
You'l grant are pretty helpes, kill not so many
(I meane so many noble) as your loves do,
Rather your lewdnesse, I crave your mercy women.
Be not offended if I anger ye.
I am sure ye have touch'd me deep, I came to be merry,
And with my children, but to see one ruin'd
By this fell accident— are they all dead?
If they be, speake?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: What newes?

div.stage: Enter Beronte, Alcidon, Clarinda, following with a letter,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What dead? ye pose me;
I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: My brother Lidian, Clarange, and their seconds.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Here is one of 'em, and sure this Gentleman's alive.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: I hope so, so is your son sir, so is brave Clarange:
They fought indeed, and they were hurt sufficiently;
We were all hurt, that bred the generall rumour,
But friends againe all, and like friends we parted.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Heard ye of Lisander?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yes, and miss'd him narrowly:
He was one of the combatants, fought with this Gentleman,
Second against your brother, by his wisdome
(For certainly good fortune followes him)
All was made peace, I'le tell you the rest at dinner,
For we are hungry.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: I before I eate
Must pay a vow I am sworne to; my life Madam
Was at Lisander's mercy, I live by it;
And for the noble favour, he desir'd me
To kisse your faire hand for him, offering
This second service as a Sacrifice
At the Altar of your vertues.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Come, joy on all sides;
Heaven will not suffer honest men to perish.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Be proud of such a friend.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Forgive me Madam,
It was a griefe might have concern'd you neare too.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: No worke of excellence but still Lisander,
Go thy waies worthy.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Wee'l be merry too,
Were I to speake againe, I would be wiser. Ex. Manet. Cal. Clarin. stayes Calist.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Too much of this rare cordiall makes me sick,
However I obey you.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Now or never is an apt time to move her, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.l: Your servant, I would speake with your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why dost thou looke about?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: I have private businesse
That none must heare but you. Lisander—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Nay, is not here, but would entreat this favor,
Some of your Balsome from your own hand given,
For he is much hurt, and that he thinkes would cure him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He shall have all, my prayers too.

sp.speaker: Clarind.
sp.l: But conceive, me,
It must be from your selfe immediately,
Pitty so brave a Gentleman should perish,
He is superstitious, and he holds your hand
Of infinite power: I would not urge this Madam,
But only in a mans extreames, to helpe him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Let him come (good wench) 'tis that I wish, I am happy in't,
My husband his true friend, my noble father,
The faire Olinda, all desire to see him;
He shall have many hands.

sp.speaker: Clarind.
sp.l: That he desires not,
Nor eyes, but yours to looke upon his miseries,
For then he thinkes 'twould be no perfect cure (Madam)
He would come private.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How can that be here?
I shall do wrong unto all those that honour him,
Besides my credit.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Dare ye not trust a hurt man?
Not straine a curtesie to save a Gentleman?
To save his life that has sav'd all your family?
A man that comes like a poore mortifi'd Pilgrim;
Only to beg a blessing, and depart againe?
He would but see you, that he thinkes would cure him.
But since you find fit reasons to the contrary,
And that it cannot stand with your cleare honour,
Though you best know how well he has deserv'd of ye:
I'l send him word backe, though I grieve to do it,
Grieve at my soule, for certainly 'twill kill him,
What your will is.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Stay, I will thinke upon't; where is he wench?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: If you desire to see him,
Let not that trouble you, he shall be with ye,
And in that time, that no man shall suspect ye;
Your honour Madam, is in your own free keeping;
Your care in me, in him all honesty;
If ye desire him not, let him passe by ye:
And all this businesse reckon but a dreame.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Go in, and counsell me, I would faine see him,
And willingly comfort him.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: 'Tis in your power.
And if you dare trust me, you shall do it safely,
Read that, and let that tell you, how he honours you.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Clarinda, with a Key, and Leon.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: THis happy night. Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Preserve this eagernesse
Till we meet nearer, there is something done
Will give us opportunity.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Witty girle, the plot?

sp.speaker: Clarind,
sp.l: You shall heare that at leasure,
The whole house reeles with joy at the report
Of Lidians safety, and that joy increas'd
From their affection to the brave Lisander,
In being made the happy instrument to compound
The bloudy difference.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: They will heare shortly that
Will turne their mirth to mourning, he was then
The principall meanes to save two lives, but since
There are two falne, and by his single hand,
For which his life must answer, if the King,
Whose arme is long, can reach him.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: We have now no spare time to heare stories, take this key,
'Twill make your passage to the banquetting house
I' the garden free.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You will not faile to come?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: For mine owne sake ne're doubt it? now for Lisander. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Dorilaus, Cleander, Servants with lights.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: To bed, to bed, 'tis very late.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: To bed all, I have dranke a health too much,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You'l sleep the better,
My usuall phisicke that way.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Where's your Mistris?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: She is above, but very ill and aguish:
The late fright of her brother, has much troubl'd her;
She would entreate to lye alone.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Her pleasure.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Commend my love to her, and my prayers for her health,
I'le see her ere I goe. Ex. Manet Clarin.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: All good rest to ye:
Now to my watch for Lisander, when he's furnish'd,
For mine own friend, since I stand Centinell,
I love to laugh i'th' evenings too, and may,
The priviledge of my place will warrant it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: You have done well hetherto; where are we now?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Not far from the house, I heare by th'owles,
There are many of your welch falkoners about it;
Here were a night to choose to run away with
Another mans wife, and do the feate.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Peace knave,
The house is here before us, and some may heare us;
The candles are all out.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: But one i'the parlor,
I see it simper hether, pray come this way.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Step to the garden doore, and feele and 't be open.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I am going, lucke deliver me from the saw pits,
Or I am buried quicke: I heare a dog,
No, 'tis a cricket, ha? here's a cuckold buried,
Take heed of his horns sir, here's the doore, 'tis open.

sp.speaker: Clarinda
sp.l: Whos's there?

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Friend.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sir, Lisander?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Ye are welcome, follow me, and make no noise.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Go to your horse, and keep your watch with care, sirah
And be sure ye sleep not. Ex. Lisan. Clarin.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: Send me out the dairy-maid
To play at trump with me, and keep me waking,
My fellow horse, and I now must discourse
Like two learned Almanack-makers, of the stars,
And tell what a plentifull year 'twil prove of drunkards,
If I had but a pottle of Sacke, like a sharp prickle,
To knock my nose against when I am nodding,
I should sing like a Nightingall, but I must
Keepe watch without it, I am apt to dance,
Good fortune guide me from the faires circles. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Clarinda with a Taper, and Lisander with a Pistole, two Chaires set out.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Come neare, Caliste sitting behind a Curtaine.
I'le leave ye now, draw but that Curtaine,
And have your wish; now Leon I am for thee.
We that are servants must make use of stoln houres,
And be glad of snatch'd occasions. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lisand.
sp.l: Shee is asleepe,
Fierce love hath clos'd his lights, I may looke on her,
Within her eyes 'has lock'd his graces up,
I may behold and live; how sweet she breathes?
The orient morning breaking out in odors,
Is not so full of perfumes, as her breath is;
She is the abstract of all excellence, and scornes a paralell.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Your servant, your most obedient slave (adored Lady)
That comes but to behold those eyes againe,
And pay some vowes I have to sacred beauty,
And so passe by; I am blind as ignorance,
And know not where I wander, how I live,
Till I receive from their bright influence
Light to direct me, for devotions sake,
You are the Saint I tread these holy steps to.
And holy Saints are all relenting sweetnesse;
Be not inrag'd nor be not angry with me;
The greatest attribute of heaven is mercy;
And 'tis the crowne of justice, and the glory
Where it may kill with right, to save with pitty.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why do you kneele, I know you come to mock me,
T' upbraid me with the benefits you have giv'n me,
Which are too many, and too mighty sir,
For my returne; and I confesse 'tis justice,
That for my cruelty you should despise me,
And I expect however you are calme now,
A foyle you strive to set your cause upon,
It will breake out; Caliste is unworthy,
Coy, proud, disdaine full, I acknowledge all,
Colder of comfort than the frozen North is,
And more a stranger to Lisanders worth,
His youth and faith then it becomes her gratitude,
I blush to grant it, yet take this along,
A soveraigne medicine to allay displeasure,
May be an argument to bring me off too;
She is married, and she is chaste; how sweet that sounds?
How it perfumes all ayre 'tis spoken in?
O deare Lisander, would you breake this union?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: No, I adore it: let me kisse your hand,
And seale the faire faith of a Gentleman on it.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You are truly valiant, would it not afflict you
To have the horrid name of coward touch you?
Such is the whore to me.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I nobly thanke ye;
And may I be the same when I dishonour ye;
This I may do againe. Kissing her hand.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ye may, and worthily;
Such comforts maids may grant with modesty,
And neither make her poore, nor wrong her bounty;
Noble Lisander, how fond now am I of ye?
I heard you were hurt.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: You dare not heale me Lady?
I am hurt here; how sweetly now she blushes?
Excellent objects kill our sight, she blinds me;
The roses in the pride of May shew pale to her;
O tyrant custome! and O coward honour!
How ye compell me to put on mine owne chaines?
May I not kisse ye now in superstition?
For you appeare a thing that I would kneele to:
Let me erre that way. Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ye shall erre for once, I have a kind of noble pity on you,
Among your manly sufferings, make this most,
To erre no farther in desire, for then sir,
Ye adde unto the gratitudes I owe you;
And after death, your deare friends soule shall blesse you.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I am wondrous honest.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I dare try. Kisses.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I have tasted a blessednesse too great for dull mortality
Once more and let me dye.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I dare not murther,
How will maids curse me if I kill with kisses?
And young men flye th' embraces of faire virgins?
Come pray sit down, but let's talke temperately.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Is my deare friend a bed?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes, and asleep;
Secure asleep, 'tis midnight too Lisander,
Speake not so loud.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: You see I am a Statue,
I could not stand else as I had eaten Ice,
Or tooke into my bloud a drowzie poyson,
And natures noblest, brightest flame burne in me;
Midnight? and I stand quietly to behold so?
The alarme rung, and I sleep like a coward?
I am worne away, my faith, and dull obedience
Like crutches, carry my decayed body
Down to the grave, I have no youth within me,
Yet happily you love too.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Love with honour.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Honour? what's that? 'tis but a specious title
We should not prize too high.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Dearer than life.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: The value of it, is as time has made it,
And time and custome have too far insulted,
We are no Gods, to be alwaies tyed to strictnesse,
'Tis a presumption to shew too like 'em;
March but an houre or two under loves ensignes,
We have examples of great memories—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: But foule ones too, that greatnesse cannot cover;
That wife that by example sins, sins double,
And puls the curtaine open to her shame too;
Me thinkes to enjoy you thus—

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: 'Tis no joy Lady,
A longing bride if she stop here, would cry,
The Bridegroome too, and with just cause curse Hymen;
But yeild a little, be one houre a woman,
(I do not speake this to compell you Lady)
And give your will but motion, let it stirre
But in the taste of that weake feares call evill,
Try it to understand it, wee'l do no thing,
You'l never come to know pure good else.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Fie sir.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I have found a way, let's slip into this errour
As Innocents, that know not what we did;
As we were dreaming both let us embrace;
The sin is none of ours then, but our fancies;
What have I said? what blasphemie to honour?
O my base thoughts! pray ye take this and shoot me.
My villaine thoughts? Noise within.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I weep your miserie, and would to heaven-what noise?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: It comes on louder.
Kill me, and save your selfe; save your faire honour,
And lay the fault on me, let my life perish,
My base lascivious life, shoote quickely Lady,

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Not for the world, retire behind the hangings,
And there stand close— my husband, close Lisander.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Dearest, are you well? Enter Cleander with a Taper.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O my sad heart; my head, my head.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Alas poore soule! what do you out of your bed?
You take cold my Caliste: how do ye?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Not so well sir to lye by ye, my brothers fright—

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: I had a frightfull dreame too,
A very frightfull dreame my best Caliste:
Me thought there came a Dragon to your Chamber,
A furious Dragon (wife) I yet shake at it:
Are all things well?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Shall I shoote him?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: No. All well Sir.
'T was but your care of me, your loving care,
Which alwaies watches.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: And me thought he came
As if he had risen thus out of his den,
As I do from these hangings.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Dead.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hold good Sir.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: And forc'd ye in his armes thus.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Twas but fancie
That troubled ye, here's nothing to disturbe me,
Good sir to rest againe, and I am now drousie,
And will to bed; make no noise deare husband,
But let me sleep: before you can call any body I am a bed.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: This, and sweet rest dwell with ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Come out againe, and as you love Lisander,
Make haste away, you see his mind is troubled:
Do you know the doore ye came at?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Well sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And can ye hit it readily?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I warrant ye;
And must I go? must here end all my happinesse?
Here in a dreame, as if it had no substance?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: For this time friend, or here begin our ruines;
We are both miserable.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: This is some comfort
In my afflictions; they are so full already,
They can find no encrease.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Deare speake no more.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: You must be silent then.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Farewell Lisander, thou joy of man farewell.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Farewell bright Lady,
Honour of woman-kind, a heavenly blessing.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Be ever honest.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I will be a dog else;
The vertues of your mind I'le make my library,
In which I'le study the celestiall beauty:
Your constancie, my armour that I'le fight in:
And on my sword your chastity shall sit,
Terror to rebell bloud.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Once more farewell: Noise within.
O that my modestie cou'd hold you still sir,— he comes againe.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Heaven keep my hand from murther,
Murther of him I love.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Away deare friend,
Down to the garden staires, that way Lisander,
We are betrai'd else. Ent. Clea.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Honour guard the Innocent. Exit. Lis.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Stil up? I fear'd your health.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Has miss'd him happily;
I am going now: I have done my meditations,
My heart's almost at peace.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: To my warme bed then.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I will pray ye lead. A Pistoll shot within

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A Pistoll shot i'th' house?
At these houres? sure some theefe, some murtherer:
Rise ho, rise all, I am betraide.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O fortune!
O giddy thing! he has met some opposition,
And kil'd; I am confounded, lost for ever. Enter Dorilaus

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Theeves, my noble father, villaines, and Rogues.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Indeed, I heard a Pistoll, let's search about.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To bed againe, they are gone sir,
I will not bid you thanke my valour for't;
Gone at the garden doore; there were a dozen,
And bravely arm'd, I saw 'em.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: I am glad, glad at the heart.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: One shot at me, and miss'd me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No, 'twas at me, the bullet flew close by me,
Close by my eare; another had a huge Sword,
Flourish'd it thus; but at the point I met him,
But the Rogue taking me to be your Lordship,
(As sure your name is terrible, and we
Not much unlike in the darke) roar'd out aloud,
'Tis the kill cow Dorilaus, and away
They ran as they had flowne: now you must love me,
Or feare me for my courage wench.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: O Rogue?
O lying Rogue, Lisander stumbled Madam,
At the staires head, and in the fall the shot went off;
Was gone before they rose.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I thanke heaven for't.

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.l: I was frighted too, it spoyl'd my game with Leon.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You must sit up; and they had come to your Chamber
What pranks would they have plaid: how came the doore open?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I heard 'em when they forc'd it; up I rose,
Took Durindana in my hand; and like
Orlando, issu'd forth.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: I know you are valiant.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: To bed again.
And be you henceforth provident, at sun-rising
We must part for a while.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: When you are a bed,
Take leave of her, there 'twill be worth the taking;
Here 'tis but a cold ceremony, ere long
Wee'l find Lisander, or we have ill fortune.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Locke all the doores fast.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Though they all stood open,
My name writ on the doore, they dare not enter. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Claran, Frier with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: Turnd Hermit?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Yes, and a devout one too: I heard him preach.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: That lessens my beliefe,
For though I grant my Lidian a scholler
As far as fits a Gentleman, he hath studied
Humanity, and in that he is a Master;
Civility of manners, courtship, Armes;
But never aim'd at (as I could perceive)
The deep points of divinity.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: That confirmes his
Devotion to be reall, no way tainted
With ostentation, or hypocrisie,
The cankers of Religion; his sermon
So full of gravity and with such sweetnesse
Deliver'd, that it drew the admiration
Of all the hearers on him; his own letters
To you, which witnesse he will leave the world,
And these to faire Olinda, his late Mistris,
In which he hath with all the moving language
That ever express'd Rhetorick, sollicited
The Lady to forget him, and make you
Blessed in her embraces, may remove
All scrupulous doubts.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: It strikes a sadnesse in me,
I know not what to thinke of't.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Ere he entred
His sollitary cell, he pen'd a ditty,
His long and last farewell to love, and women,
So feelingly, that I confesse however
It stands not with my order to be taken
With such Poeticall raptures; I was mov'd,
And strangely with it.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: Have you the copy?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Yes sir:
My Novice too can sing it, if you please
To give him hearing.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: And it will come timely,
For I am full of melancholy thoughts,
Against which I have heard with reason Musick
To be the speediest cure, pray you apply it.
ADieu fond love farewell you wanton powers,
I am free againe;
Thou dull disease of bloud and Idle howers.
Bewitching paine,
Flie to the fooles that sigh away their time.
My nobler love to heaven clime,
And there behold beauty still young,
That time can ne're corrupt, nor death destroy;
Immortall sweetnesse by faire Angels sung,
And honour'd by eternity and joy:
There lives my love, thether my hopes aspire;
Fond love declines, this heavenly love growes higher.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: How do ye approve it?

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: To its due desert,
It is a heavenly Hymne, no ditty father,
It passes through my eares unto my soule,
And workes divinely on it; give me leave
A little to consider; shall I be
Out done in all things? nor good of my selfe.
Nor by example? shall my loose hopes still,
The viands of a fond affection, feed me
As I were a sensuall beast, spirituall food
Refus'd by my sicke pallat? 'tis resolv'd.
How far off father, doth this new made Hermit
Make his abode?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Some two dayes journey son.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: Having reveal'd my faire intentions to ye,
I hope your piety will not deny me
Your aides to further 'em?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: That were against a good mans charity.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: My first request is,
You would some time, for reasons I will shew you,
Defer delivery of Lidians Letters
To faire Olinda.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Claran.
sp.l: For what followes,
You shall direct me; something I will do,
A new borne zeale, and friendship prompts me to. Ex.

div.stage: Enter Dorilaus, Cleander, Chamberlaine, Table, Tapers, and three stooles.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: We have supp'd well friend; let our beds be ready,
We must be stirring early,

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: They are made sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I cannot sleep yet, where's the joviall host
You told me of? 'tas been my custome ever
To parley with mine host.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: He's a good fellow,
And such a one I know you love to laugh with;
Go call your Master up.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: He cannot come sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Is he a bed with his wife?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: No certainly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Or with some other ghests?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Neither and 't like ye.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Why then he shall come by your leave my friend,
I'le fetch him up my selfe.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Indeed you'l faile sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Is he i'th' house?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: No, but he is hard by sir;
He is fast in's grave, he has been dead these three weekes.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then o' my conscience he will come but lamely,
And discourse worse.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Farewell mine honest Host then,
Mine honest merry Host; will you to bed yet?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No, not this houre, I prethee sit and chat by me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Give us a quart of wine then, wee'l be merry.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A match my son; pray let your wine be living,
Or lay it by your Master.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: It shall be quick sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Has not mine Host a wife?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A good old woman.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Another coffine, that is not so hansome;
Your Hostesses in Innes should be blith things,
Pretty, and young to draw in passengers;
She'l never fill her beds well, if she be not beauteous.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: And curteous too. Enter Chamberlaine with wine.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I, I, and a good fellow,
That will mistake sometimes a Gentleman
For her good man; well done; here's to Lisander.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: My full love meets it; make fire in our lodgings,
Wee'l trouble thee no farther; to your Son. Ex. Cham.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Put in Clarange too; off with't, I thanke ye;
This wine drinkes merrier still, O for mine Host now,
Were he alive againe, and well dispos'd,
I would so claw his pate.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Y'are a hard drinker.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I love to make mine Host drunke, he will lye then
The rarest, and the roundest, of his friends,
His quarrels, and his ghests, and they are the best bauds too
Take 'em in that tune.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: You know all.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I did son, but time, and armes have worne me out

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.p: 'Tis late sir, I heare none stirring. A lute is struck.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Hark, what's that, a Lute?
'Tis at the doore I thinke.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: The doores are shut fast.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Tis morning sure, the Fidlers are got up
To fright mens sleepes, have we ne're a pispot ready?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Now I remember, I have heard mine Host that's dead,
Touch a lute rarely, and as rarely sing too,
A brave still meane.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I would give a brace of French Crownes
To see him rise and Fidle.
TIs late and cold, stirre up the fire;
Sit close, and draw the Table nigher;
Be merry, and drinke wine that's old,
A hearty medicine 'gainst a cold.
Your beds of want on downe the best,
Where you shall tumble to your rest;
I could wish you wenches too,
But I am dead and cannot do;
Call for the best the house may ring,
Sacke, White, and Claret let them bring,
And drinke apace while breath you have,
You'l find but cold drinke in the grave;
Plover, Patridge for your dinner,
And a Capon for the sinner,
You shall find ready when you are up,
And your horse shall have his sup:
Welcome shall flye round,
And I shall smile though under ground.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Harke, a Song, now as I live, it is his voice.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: He sings well, the devill has a pleasant pipe.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: The fellow lyed sure, Enter Host.
He is not dead, he's here: how pale he lookes?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Is this he?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: You are welcome noble Gentlemen,
My brave old ghest most welcome.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Lying knaves,
To tell us you were dead, come sit downe by us,
We thanke ye for your Song.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Would 't had been better.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Speake, are ye dead?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Yes indeed am I Gentlemen,
I have been dead these three weekes.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then here's to ye, to comfort your cold body.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: What do ye meane? stand further off.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I will stand nearer to him,
Shall he come out on's coffin to beare us company,
And we not bid him welcome? come mine Host,
Mine honest Host, here's to ye.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Spirits sir, drinke not?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Why do ye appeare?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: To waite upon ye Gentlemen,
'thas been my duty living, now my farewell;
I feare ye are not us'd accordingly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I could wish you warmer company mine Host,
How ever we are us'd?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Next to entreate a courtesie,
And then I goe to peace.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Is't in our power?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Yes and 'tis this, to see my body buried
In holy ground, for now I lye unhallowed,
By the clarkes fault; let my new grave be made
Amongst good fellowes, that have died before me,
And merry Hostes of my kind.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And forty stoopes of wine dranke at thy funerall.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Do you know our travell?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Yes, to seeke your friends,
That in afflictions wander now.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Seeke 'em no farther, but be confident
They shall returne in peace.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: There's comfort yet.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Pray ye one word more, is't in your power mine Host,
Answer me softly, some houres before my death,
To give me warning?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I cannot tell ye truly,
But if I can, so much alive I lov'd ye,
I will appeare againe, adieu. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Adieu sir.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I am troubl'd; these strange apparitions are
For the most part fatall.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: This if told, will not
Find credit, the light breakes a pace, let's lye downe
And take some little rest, an houre or two,
Then do mine hostes desire, and so returne,
I do beleeve him.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: So do I, to rest sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Clarinda?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Is the house well ordered?
The doores look'd to now in your Masters absence?
Your care, and diligence amongst the Servants?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: I am stirring Madam.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: So thou art Clarinda,
More then thou ought'st I am sure, why dost thou blush?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: I do not blush.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why dost thou hang thy head wench?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Madam, ye are deceiv'd, I looke upright,
I understand ye not: she has spied Leon, aside.
Shame of his want of caution.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Looke on me; what, blush againe?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: 'Tis more then I know Madam;
I have no cause that I find yet.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Examine then.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Your Ladyship is set I thinke to shame me.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Do not deserve't. who lay with you last night?
What bedfellow had ye? none of the maids came neare ye.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Madam they did.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Twas one in your Cosins cloathes then,
And wore a sword; and sure I keep no Amazons;
Wench do not lye, 'twill but proclame thee guilty;
Lyes hide our sins like nets; like perspectives,
They draw offences nearer still, and greater:
Come tell the truth.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: You are the strangest Lady
To have these doubts of me; how have I liv'd Madam?
And which of all my carefull services deserves these shames?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Leave facing? 'twill not serve ye,
This impudence becomes thee worse then lying?
I thought ye had liv'd well, and I was proud of't;
But you are pleas'd to abuse my thoughts; who was't?
Honest repentance yet will make the fault lesse.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Do ye compell me? do you stand so strict too?
Nay, then have at ye; I shall rub that sore Madam▪
(Since ye provoke me) will but vexe your Ladyship;
Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I will know.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: For your own peace,
The peace of your owne conscience aske no farther;
Walke in, and let me alone.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: No, I will know all.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Why, then I'le tell ye, 't was a man I lay with,
Never admire, 'tis easie to be done, Madam,
And usuall too, a proper man I lay with;
Why should you vexe at that? young as Lisander,
And able too; I grudge not at your pleasure,
Why should you stir at mine? I steale none from ye,

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And dost thou glory in this sin?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.p: I am glad on't, to glory in't is for a mighty Lady That may command.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why didst thou name Lisander?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Does it anger ye? does it a little gall ye?
I know it does, why would ye urge me Lady?
Why would ye be so curious to compell me?
I nam'd Lisander as my president,
The rule I err'd by, you love him, I know it,
I grudg'd not at it, but am pleas'd it is so;
And by my care and diligence you enjoy'd him.
Shall I for keeping counsell, have no comfort?
Will you have all your selfe? ingrosse all pleasure?
Are ye so hard hearted? why do ye blush now Madam?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: My anger blushes, not my shame base woman.

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.l: I'le make your shame blush, since you put me to't
Who lay with you t'other night?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: With me? ye monstor.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Whose sweet embraces circled ye? not your husbands;
I wonder ye dare touch me in this point Madam?
Stir her against ye in whose hand your life lies?
More then your life your honour? what smug Amazon
Was that I brought you? that maid had ne're a petticoat?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: She'l halfe perswade me anon, I am a beast too,
And I mistrust my selfe, though I am honest
For giving her the Helme, thou knowest Clarinda,
(Ev'n in thy conscience) I was ever vertuous;
As far from lust in meeting with Lisander
As the pure wind in welcoming the morning;
In all the conversation I had with him,
As free, and innocent, as you'd faire heaven;
Didst not thou perswade me too?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: Yes, I had reason for't,
And now you are perswaded I'le make use on't.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If I had sin'd thus, and my youth entic'd me,
The noblenesse and beauty of his person,
Beside the mighty benefits I am bound to,
Is this sufficient warrant for thy weakenesse?
If I had been a whore, and crav'd thy counsell
In the conveyance of my fault, and faithfulnesse,
Thy secrecie, and truth in hiding of it;
Is it thy justice to repay me thus?
To be the Master sinner to compell me?
And build thy lusts security on mine honour?

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.l: They that love this sin, love their security;
Prevention Madam is the naile I knock'd at,
And I have hit it home, and so I'le hold it,
And you must pardon me, and be silent too,
